description: This clinical course is designed to help prospective advanced practice nurses develop advanced skills in physical and developmental assessment of children in a variety of well-child, clinic and hospital settings. Data collection, data interpretation, and hypothesis formulations are emphasized for the purpose of clinical decision making. The role of the advanced practice nurse in assessment of primary health care issues and health promotion is incorporated throughout the course. Collaboration as an integral part of assessment will be an ongoing focus.
name: PHYSICAL ASSESSMENT AND CLINICAL DECISION MAKING: CLINICAL I

section.name: PHYSICAL ASSESSMENT AND CLINICAL DECISION MAKING: CLINICAL I

values.comments:
This clinical course is designed to help prospective advanced practice nurses develop advanced skills in physical and developmental assessment of children in a variety of well-child, clinic and hospital settings. Data collection, data interpretation, and hypothesis formulations are emphasized for the purpose of clinical decision making. The role of the advanced practice nurse in assessment of primary health care issues and health promotion is incorporated throughout the course. Collaboration as an integral part of assessment will be an ongoing focus. This course is characterized by it’s strong clinical work which involves a small group of students being assigned certain “patients” they are must assess. This course also requires registration for both lecture and laboratory.

Many students appreciated the experience gained from the course. Comments centered on the idea that the course was an “overall good experience.” Several students commented as well on the difficult time frames of the course, during which they worked right up until the deadline. Some felt that the clinical work was “hectic” and, therefore, was a bit challenging. Most students felt that a substantial amount of effort was required for this course, but that it was worth the experience gained.

Students generally felt that there needed to be more guidance from teachers. One student commented, “If I didn't hunt down an instructor for help/guidance, I typically did not see one.” The general consensus was that more supervision and assistance was needed.

Overall, students felt that the class was difficult because it was demanding. Students seemed to agree that the “grading is too subjective.” There were also some concerns over the lack of feedback that students received regarding their assignments. Many did not know where their grades or growth in the course stood as a result.

This clinical course is designed to help prospective advanced practice nurses develop advanced skills in physical and developmental assessment of children in a variety of well-child, clinic and hospital settings. Data collection, data interpretation, and hypothesis formulations are emphasized for the purpose of clinical decision making. The role of the advanced practice nurse in assessment of primary health care issues and health promotion is incorporated throughout the course. Collaboration as an integral part of assessment will be an ongoing focus. This course also requires registration for both lecture and laboratory.

Many students appreciated the experience gained from the course. Comments centered on the idea that the course was an “overall good experience.” Several students commented as well on the difficult time frames of the course, during which they worked right up until the deadline. Some felt that the clinical work was “hectic” and, therefore, was a bit challenging. Most students felt that a substantial amount of effort was required for this course, but that it was worth the experience gained.

Students generally felt that there needed to be more guidance from teachers. One student commented, “If I didn't hunt down an instructor for help/guidance, I typically did not see one.” The general consensus was that more supervision and assistance was needed.

Overall, students felt that the class was difficult because it was demanding. Students seemed to agree that the “grading is too subjective.” There were also some concerns over the lack of feedback that students received regarding their assignments. Many did not know where their grades or growth in the course stood as a result.

This clinical course is designed to help prospective advanced practice nurses develop advanced skills in physical and developmental assessment of children in a variety of well-child, clinic and hospital settings. Data collection, data interpretation, and hypothesis formulations are emphasized for the purpose of clinical decision making. The role of the advanced practice nurse in assessment of primary health care issues and health promotion is incorporated throughout the course. Collaboration as an integral part of assessment will be an ongoing focus.

Students generally reported an overall good experience working with children in the Penn Children’s Center. One student commented that this clinic “met learning needs very well.” The foremost complaint was that there were too many students and not enough supervision. Students reported “anxiety” and feeling “overwhelmed” because there were not enough instructors to provide assistance.

Many students recognized that the unbalanced ratio of instructors to students made it difficult for students to receive individualized attention and help. One student commented, “If I didn’t hunt out instructors for help/guidance, I typically did not see one.” Several students would preferred to have seen more weekly feedback in the form of constructive criticism and praise.

The prerequisites for this course include NURS 560, 710, 711 and corequisite NURS 713. This class is geared towards nursing students only.

values.name: PHYSICAL ASSESSMENT AND CLINICAL DECISION MAKING: CLINICAL I
